awd_titl_txt: UNS:Role of Cell-Mediated ECM Remodeling in Pluripotent Stem Cell Differentiation
awd_abstract_narration:
1508950
Palecek, Sean P.    

A significant roadblock impeding realization of the promise of human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) is the inability to efficiently biomanufacture normal cells from hPSCs, in a large part resulting from an incomplete understanding of how hPSCs decide how to differentiate to more specialized cell types.  These cell fate decisions are influenced by chemical and mechanical signals present in the cell environment. This project will investigate how cell remodeling of their extracellular matrix (ECM) environment affects differentiation to various testbed lineages including heart cells, blood vessel cells, brain cells, and skin cells. This deeper understanding of mechanisms of stem cell differentiation will then inform design of more efficient, defined protocols for guiding stem cells to cells in desired lineages.  Thus, the project outcomes will have direct implications on producing stem cell-derived cells and tissues at lab scale or in biomanufacturing applications.

This project will test the hypothesis that extracellular matrix remodeling by hPSCs during differentiation is a key regulator of stem cell differentiation fate.  The project will identify novel autocrine/paracrine mechanisms of regulation of hPSC fate via ECM remodeling, and demonstrate the importance of designing materials and scaffolds that enhance or inhibit ECM remodeling during hPSC differentiation.  To test this hypothesis, proteomic analysis will be used to identify ECM components produced during hPSC directed differentiation to cardiomyocytes, endothelial cells, neurons, and keratinocytes.  These experiments will identify candidate cell-synthesized ECM proteins that regulate specific hPSC differentiation fates. To test the prediction that ECM synthesis is necessary for efficient directed differentiation, CRISPR/Cas9-mediated ECM gene knockout experiments will be employed to assess how inhibiting matrix production affects hPSC differentiation to cardiomyocytes, vascular endothelial cells, neurons, and keratinocytes.  Finally, to test the hypothesis that matrix remodeling via proteolytic degradation of ECM affects hPSC differentiation efficiency, matrix metalloprotease expression and activity will be monitored during directed differentiation, then chemical inhibitors and genetic knockouts will be used to quantify the contributions of these proteases during directed differentiation.  Education and outreach activities described in this proposal will also train stem cell engineers at the graduate and undergraduate levels, and will provide outreach to K-12 students, K-12 teachers, undergraduate students, and the general public on technical, ethical, and political aspects of stem cell science and engineering.

This award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of CBET is co-funded by the Biomaterials Program of the Division of Materials Research.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
During development, cells secrete the scaffold (termed extracellular matrix or ECM) upon which they reside.  The ECM provides structural support to the tissue as well as important cues that guide cell division, survival, and development.  In this project we used induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) to identify changes in ECM production that occur during heart development.  We leveraged recent advances in differentiating iPSCs through heart progenitors to beating cardiomyocytes and developed a defined process for generating cardiac fibroblasts, a cell type that produces significant amounts of ECM and other growth factors, from iPSCs.

Our approach used -omics technologies to profile gene expression and protein production at various stages of differentiation, from primitive pluripotent cells to fully differentiated cardiomyocytes.  Transcriptomics profiled all genes expressed in the population (bulk RNA sequencing) as well as genes expressed by individual cells (single cell RNA sequencing).  These transcriptomics experiments identified ECM genes as among the most highly expressed genes in developing cardiomyocytes.  This result was somewhat surprising because most heart ECM was thought to be synthesized by cardiac fibroblasts, but our results suggest that cardiomyocytes may also play a substantial role in cardiac ECM production.  Our transcriptomics also determined that ECM gene expression is very dynamic during heart development.  For example, collagens are produced at all stages of differentiation, but the specific isoforms of collagens change during cardiomyocyte differentiation and maturation.  Our results indicate that ECM gene expression can be used to monitor differentiation of cardiomyocytes and suggest that the ECM produced by cardiomyocytes plays an important role in driving heart development.

Our unbiased analysis of gene expression during cardiomyocyte differentiation also revealed other new insights not directly related to ECM production.  For example, we identified many changes in expression of structural and metabolic genes during differentiation.  The datasets we generated will be of use to us and others to better understand the progression of cell states during cardiomyocyte development.  As one example, our statistical analysis demonstrated that cytoskeletal gene isoform production is most highly predictive of developmental state. 

During the course of this project we also developed a new process to differentiate iPSCs to cardiac fibroblasts.  In the chambers of the heart, the majority of cardiac fibroblasts originate from a thin layer of cells coating the surface of the heart, called the epicardium.  During development and injury, the epicardial cells turn into fibroblasts and other cell types, crawl into the heart muscle, and assist in tissue generation or repair.  We identified culture conditions that direct iPSC-derived epicardial cells to cardiac fibroblasts to allow us to investigate how cardiac fibroblast ECM production influences heart development.  Our cardiac fibroblast protocol also provides the stem cell and bioengineering research communities with a source of developmentally-relevant cardiac fibroblasts for studying the roles of these cells in development and disease, screening the effects of drugs on cardiac fibroblasts, and developing cellular therapies to regenerate damaged heart tissue.

We also developed a proteomics pipeline to characterize ECM synthesized by cardiomyocytes and cardiac fibroblasts.  Our proteomics results with cardiomyocytes were consistent with gene expression studies, where high levels of laminins and collagens were detected in the ECM.  In contrast, iPSC-derived cardiac fibroblasts primarily synthesized fibronectin.  These findings suggest that different cell types cooperate during heart development to produce the complex ECM that supports heart development and function.  Also, the ECM synthesized by iPSC-derived cardiac fibroblasts is more similar to that produced by primary fetal cardiac fibroblasts than adult cardiac fibroblasts.  We hypothesize that these fetal-like iPSC-derived cardiac fibroblasts will produce an ECM that is more regenerative and less scarring in nature than adult cardiac fibroblasts, but this needs to be studied in greater detail in follow-up projects.

In summary, the intellectual merits of this project include: (1) development of an efficient, defined protocol to differentiate iPSCs to cardiac fibroblasts through a developmentally relevant epicardial cell, (2) genomic and proteomic datasets profiling dynamics of cardiomyocyte and cardiac fibroblast ECM production through differentiation, and (3) novel insights into the roles of cardiomyocytes and cardiac fibroblasts in producing the heart ECM during development.  Together, these impacts have the potential to improve strategies to use iPSC-derived cells to understand development and disease and engineer heart tissues to benefit human health.

Broader impacts of this study include providing research training in stem cell engineering to several graduate and undergraduate students who are continuing research in cell-based therapies in academic and industry positions.  This project also generated educational materials for high school students and teachers as part of the Morgridge Summer Science Camp.  We provided hands-on training to camp participants in differentiating iPSCs to cardiomyocytes and using these cardiomyocytes to assess the effects of various drugs on heart function.

 


Last Modified: 08/07/2020
Modified by: Sean P Palecek
